importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Release year of the original South Korean publication of the memoir 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki', which sparked widespread attention and discussion about mental health in South Korea.
Year of English translation of the memoir, which led to international popularity and inclusion on the Sunday Times Bestsellers List and a New York Times recommendation.
Release year of Baek Se-hee's follow-up memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Still Want to Eat Tteokbokki', which continued her exploration of long-term depression and mental health.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from 2018 to 2025 marks the rise and global impact of Baek Se-hee’s mental health advocacy through her memoirs, influencing public discourse on depression and therapy in South Korea and internationally.

keyTakeAways: Baek Se-hee, a South Korean author, died at age 35 after writing a bestselling memoir that openly addressed her struggles with depression and the desire to die while still craving simple pleasures like tteokbokki.

Her memoirs, especially 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki' and its sequel, became a cultural phenomenon in South Korea and gained international acclaim, reaching bestseller lists in the UK and US.

The memoirs brought significant attention to mental health discussions, particularly dysthymia (chronic low-level depression), and helped normalize conversations about therapy and emotional suffering.
Baek donated her organs — heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys — after death, saving the lives of five people, highlighting her legacy of selflessness and compassion.
Her younger sister, Baek Da-hee, and English translator Anton Hur both paid tribute, emphasizing her kindness, emotional honesty, and impact on readers globally.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Serves as a symbolic element in Baek Se-hee’s memoirs, representing small, comforting pleasures that contrast with her desire to die, highlighting the complexity of human emotions.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The agency announced Baek Se-hee’s death and confirmed her organ donation, linking her legacy to public health and life-saving altruism.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She publicly mourned Baek Se-hee’s death, expressing her admiration for her sibling’s kindness and emotional honesty, adding a personal and familial dimension to the story.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He translated Baek Se-hee’s work into English and paid tribute to her, underscoring the international reach and cultural impact of her writing.

summaryOfNewsArticle: South Korean author Baek Se-hee, known for her deeply personal memoirs exploring depression and the desire to die while still enjoying life's small pleasures like tteokbokki, has died at age 35. Her first memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Want to Eat Tteokbokki', published in 2018, became a cultural phenomenon in South Korea and gained global attention after being translated into English in 2022, reaching bestseller lists in the UK and being recommended by the New York Times. Her follow-up memoir, 'I Want to Die but I Still Want to Eat Tteokbokki', further detailed her ongoing struggle with dysthymia. Baek, who studied creative writing and worked in publishing, underwent therapy for depression, which inspired her writing. She donated her heart, lungs, liver, and both kidneys, saving the lives of five people. Her sister and English translator both paid heartfelt tributes to her legacy of kindness and emotional honesty, highlighting her impact on both personal mental health discourse and global readership.
title: Baek Se-hee, author of bestselling memoir 'I Want To Die But I Want To Eat Tteokbokki,' dead at 35
